7. Construction of fundamental matrices

Starting from the fundamental tensor families $\{f_{k}, g_{k}\}$ for $L$ on a sector $\overline{\Omega }\backslash 0$, we want to construct the columns of the matrices $m$ and $\tilde{m}$, i.e., the solutions to (2.20)(2.21). The first step is to show that the fundamental tensors are decomposable, i.e.,

$$\begin{equation*} f_{k}=v_{1}\wedge \cdots \wedge v_{k},\qquad g_{k}=w_{k}\wedge \cdots \wedge w_{n}, \end{equation*}$$

for some vector-valued functions $v_{j},\ w_{j}$.

8. Global properties of fundamental matrices; the transition matrix $\delta$

In this section we summarize some of the results of 7, and we investigate $m$ and $\tilde{m}$ as $z\rightarrow \infty$ and as $z \rightarrow 0$.

In view of 6 and 7, we expect the behavior of $m$ as $z\rightarrow 0$ to be governed by the quantities

8.14 $$\begin{equation} \Delta _{k0}=\lim _{z\rightarrow 0}z^{k(n-k)}\Delta _{k}(z). \cssId{texmlid459}{\tag{8.14}} \end{equation}$$

To conclude this examination of the limit $z\rightarrow 0$, we find the asymptotics in $x$ of the terms in the expansion.

For later use we now examine some of the higher terms in the expansion

8.26 $$\begin{equation} m(x,z)d_{z}^{-1}\sim \sum _{\nu =0}^{\infty }z^{\nu }m^{(\nu )}(x),\qquad \quad z\rightarrow 0,\ z\in \overline{\Omega }. \cssId{texmlid462}{\tag{8.26}} \end{equation}$$

Note that

$$\begin{equation*} m^{(\nu )}(x)=\lim _{z\rightarrow 0}\frac{1}{\nu !}\left(\frac{\partial }{\partial z}\right)^{\nu }\ [m(x,z)d_{z}^{-1}]. \end{equation*}$$

We shall actually be interested in the modification

8.27 $$\begin{equation} M^{(\nu )}(x,z) = \left(\frac{\partial }{\partial z}\right)^{\nu }\ [m(x,z)e^{ixzJ}d_{z}^{-1}]. \cssId{texmlid463}{\tag{8.27}} \end{equation}$$

Let us now rephrase Theorems8.28 and8.19 in terms of the matrix

$$\begin{equation*} \psi (x, z)=m(x, z)e^{ixzJ}=M^{(0)}(x,z)d_{z} \end{equation*}$$

and its derivatives. Note that

$$\begin{align*} \lim _{z\rightarrow 0}\left(\frac{\partial }{\partial z}\right)^{\nu }\psi _{k}(x, z)&=\lim _{z\rightarrow 0}\left(\frac{\partial }{\partial z}\right)^{\nu } [z^{k-1}M_{k}^{(0)}(x, z)]\\ &=\left\{\begin{array}{ll} 0, \qquad \nu < k - 1,\\(k -1)!M_{k}^{(\nu -k+1)}(x),\qquad k -1 \leq \nu < n. \end{array}\right. \end{align*}$$
